‚ú® ICONIC ‚ú® Last night, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez beat out incumbent Joe Crowley, an establishment Democrat, in NY-14‚Äôs first Democratic congressional primary in 14 years. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, a 28-year-old socialist, ran an insurgent campaign focused on Medicare for all, abolishing Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), and tuition-free higher education. Her victory is the first since 2014 to unseat an incumbent Democrat, and having raised about a 10th of Crowley‚Äôs campaign funds, signals a huge win for grassroots organizing and progressive Democrats. Representing part of the eastern Bronx and Queens, Ocasio-Cortez said last night, ‚Äúwe beat a machine with a movement.‚Äù Read more at ThinkProgress.org #thinkprogress #ny14 #2018primaries #ocasio #poscon #democracy #socialism

‚úäüèΩ With hurricane season only days away, Puerto Rico is nowhere close to recovered from the impact of last fall's Hurricane Maria, which killed more than 5,700 people, according to a new study released this week. Blue tarps still remain in place of roofs for residents across the island and many homes rely on generators for power. But the island's recovery has also been a tale of resilience, as much as of frustration. Community leaders are hard at work ensuring that low-income Puerto Ricans are not forgotten as the island's recovery moves forward, while protesters last week told ThinkProgress they wished Puerto Rico's pre-existing problems earned the same attention as its post-hurricane struggles. Head to ThinkProgress.org to read more. #puertorico #hurricanemaria #community üì∏: E.A. Crunden

The American health care system frequently fails those who need psychiatric hospitalization as overtaxed psychiatric care facilities often lack the training and expertise to competently treat transgender patients. 
ThinkProgress spoke with an array of former patients, advocates, providers, and experts about the unique factors that make an already traumatic time and an already dysfunctional system even more acutely difficult for trans and gender-nonconforming people ‚Äî a segment of the population with some of the highest rates of suicide attempts ‚Äî and about the baby steps that are underway to address the crisis. Click the link in bio to read more.

On Saturday, protesters with the March for Black Women and the March for Racial Justice rallied at nearby parks before marching together to the Department of Justice and onto the National Mall. The protests started coming together last June, after a jury acquitted the Minnesota police officer who shot and killed Philando Castile. While centered on the movement for black lives, the protests addressed a broad range of issues that affect people of color, from mass incarceration to poverty to immigration reform to sexual assault to health care access. Those issues have been around for a long time, but there was also a palpable sense among those in attendance that the clock is turning back under President Donald Trump. "[It's] like when my parents were little," Gwendlen Green, 54, who traveled to the march from upstate New York with her sister, told ThinkProgress. "It's going back to that." #m4rj #m4bw

50-year-old Robert has never voted in his life due to a non-violent drug crime he committed as a teen, but he'll finally be able to cast a ballot in November. "I felt like less than a citizen," he told @alicemirandao. Until last month, Virginia was one of just 4 states that took away the voting rights of most ex-felons for the rest of their lives. GOP law makers say they'll sue to block 200,000 people like Robert from being able to vote. We will follow this story as it develops. #election2016 #vote #virginia #rva

Political reporter @kira_lerner accompanied Kentucky resident Michael Hiser to the polls yesterday, where he voted for his first time ever. Hiser was lucky to get a pardon from the governor in order to regain his voting rights after a felony conviction, but more than 140,000 Kentuckians are still permanently disenfranchised because of their criminal records. #KYprimary #2016election #voting

Tonight is my last night hosting this Instagram account as well as my last night in Haiti. Every time I come here, it becomes harder to leave. We've learned so, so much on this trip--about the complexities of Vodou, about the history of Haiti, about Haitian art, about religions of all kinds...the broad list could go on and on and the list of specifics is nearly endless. I hope that in sharing a few nuggets of what we learned, you learned something too. Until next time, Ayiti cheri. To follow my work in Mexico and beyond, follow my personal account at @meghandhaliwal, and be sure to follow my reporting partner @beenishfahmed too. M√®si ak orevwa! #Haiti #portauprince #ayiticherie #irpfellows

Haitian government is aiming to build up its tourism industry. Under former Minister of Tourism Stephanie Villedrouin, the numbers of tourists in Haiti started climbing for the first time since the 80s. And rightfully so....do you see this beach?! But it isn't only about the beaches. When asked what differentiates Haiti from the rest of the Caribbean, Director General of the Ministry of Tourism said, "Our culture, our food, but most of all our people. People are so welcoming and kind." Can't argue there. For more from Haiti, follow my personal account at @meghandhaliwal #Haiti #ayiticherie #beach #sunset #irpfellows #tourism

Haiti is in the midst of a 3 year drought, made worse by El Ni√±o. The World Food program has classified 3.6 million Haitians as "severely food insecure" and up to 70% of crops in some areas of Haiti had been lost in the past year. For more from Haiti, follow my personal account at @meghandhaliwal and my reporting partner @beenishfahmed #haiti #foodinsecurity #farming #elnino #irpfellows

This beautiful place is Saut D'eau, near Mirebalais. Saut D'eau is an important in both the Catholic and Vodou faiths--for Catholics, this spot is where the Virgin Mary of Mount Carmel appeared in a palm tree. If you remember from my last post, the Virgin is closely associated with the Vodou loa Erzulie Dantor. Also, because of the water, the place is special to the loa Damballah and Ayida Wedo. While we were there, we saw a number of small Vodou ceremonies happening as well as a few Catholic ceremonies. People travel to Saut D'eau each year in July for a massive festival in the powerful falls--a mix of Vodou and Catholic practices happening in the crowd. Religion here is so interesting because sometimes you really just can't untangle one faith from the other. For more from Haiti, check out my personal account at @meghandhaliwal #haiti #ayiticherie #sautdeau #vodou #voodoo #catholic #catholicism #irpfellows

The view from my bed at the Oloffson hotel (we stayed in the Katherine Dunham room). This painting looks like the Virgin and baby Jesus in the Byzantine icon style but actually represents Erzulie Dantor, the loa of motherhood. Remember how I said we would be talking about how Vodou played a part in Haiti's gaining of independence? Well prepare yourself for a very short crash course in Haitian history. The Haitian revolution lasted from 1791 to Haiti's independence in 1804. It is the only slave uprising in history that led to the founding of a slavery-free state and ruled by former slaves. I highly recommend reading more about the revolution because I can't cover it all here. But this was a defining moment in world history--and it all began around a Vodou ceremony in northern Haiti. Bois Ca√Øman is the historical site where, on August 14 1791, slaves from plantations in the area gathered by cover of night for a secret ceremony to mark the start of the revolution. Who was the loa they served that night? You guessed it: Erzulie Dantor. A black pig (her favorite animal sacrifice) was made to her that night, and the black pig still holds significance to Bois Ca√Øman. For more from Haiti, follow my personal account at @meghandhaliwal #haiti #erzuliedantor #loa #oloffson #oloffsonhotel #ayiticherie #boiscaiman  #theroommightvebeenalittleslanted #irpfellows

BREAKING NEWS: @berniesanders wins Wisconsin, riding a wave of support from students and other progressives in the state. @alicemirandao was on the ground reporting on how Bernie reached out to many communities often ignored by politicians. #feelthebern #primary #wisconsin #election

Reporting on Vodou in Haiti wouldn't be complete without a quick stop at the Hotel Oloffson (or as the owner Richard Morse called it to us: "The Vodou Hotel"). The Oloffson is an old gingerbread house-style hotel in Port au Prince and home to the band @ram_haiti. Headed by the hotel manager Richard Morse, the band fuses jazz and Vodou beats at a live weekly performance in the hotel. Haitians, expats and tourists alike come out to drink rhum punch and dance the night away. One of the most interesting parts of the band is that a Vodou priest named Anis (who is also part of the band) puts on a small Vodou ceremony before the performance. This way, even if audience members have never been inside a peristyle, they can get a quick glimpse of what a Vodou ceremony might look like. See that design on the floor? That's called a Vev√©, and it's a symbol for the loa being called during a Vodou ceremony. This photo was taken just before RAM jumped on stage. For more from Haiti, follow me at my personal account at @meghandhaliwal  #haiti #oloffson #veve #ram #ramhaiti #irpfellows

It's Election Day in Wisconsin! Did you know this is the first presidential election in the state's history with a strict voter ID law? They worry many will be disenfranchised by the law today. #wisconsin #badgers #election #vote #feelthebern #imwithher #journalism

The vodouizans in Souvenance on Monday spend their entire day at the sacred mapou tree. The day is full of drumming and singing, and a lot of walking in circles are the base of the majestic tree. The day is about preservation of tradition, about honoring the place where Haitians and Vodou truly come from. Many of the songs and rhythms hail from Dahomey (present day Benin). The vibe is peaceful, reverent. The sun beats down through the branches of the sacred mapou and on to its sinewy roots. Some initiates sprint around the base of the tree, other move slowly, watching their feet as one goes in front of the other--bare feet in the dirt alongside the roots. For more from Haiti, follow me along on my personal account at @meghandhaliwal and follow my reporting partner @beenishfahmed  #vodou #voodoo #irpfellows #souvenance #haiti #dahomey #ayiticherie #mapou

This is the sacred Mapou tree in Souvenance. As I've mentioned in previous posts, the Vodou ceremonies that take place at Souvenance annually are a highlight in the Vodou calendar and a highly attended event. People come from all over the country to attend the days-long ceremonies. The Mapou tree comes in to play on Monday, the day after Easter. In the early morning, initiates don outfits of pristine white and walk slowly to the Mapou tree singing songs with linguistic roots tied to West Africa. The journey of walking to the Mapou represents the journey to Africa, the land from which their ancestors were forcibly torn. I'll post more about the ceremony at the Mapou in my next post. For more from Haiti, follow me along on my personal account at @meghandhaliwal and follow my reporting partner @beenishfahmed  #vodou #voodoo #irpfellows #souvenance #haiti #dahomey #ayiticherie #mapou

Possession is an aspect of Vodou, a way for the spirits to communicate with a practitioner or to enter the earthly world with a practitioner as their vessel. At the ceremonies at Souvenance, initiates enter this muddy pool and become possessed as soon as they touch the water. Events at Souvenance honor loa of Dahomey origin--namely the Rada loa. Following me? Dahomey is present day Benin, the home of many of the slaves transported against their will to the "New World." Remember in my last post I talked about the syncretism between Catholicism and Vodou? The Rada loa are a group of loa (spirits) that are most closely syncretized with Catholicism. But back to Souvenance: in this ceremony, many initiates become possessed the moment they enter the pool. We saw a lot of people helping each other out if they were deep in trance. That's one of the things I notice most about Vodou: people are always interacting with each other, helping each other. Holding on to someone who is in trance, wiping sweat from each other's faces, dancing together, holding hands. For more from Haiti, follow me along on my personal account at @meghandhaliwal and follow my reporting partner @beenishfahmed  #vodou #voodoo #irpfellows #souvenance #haiti #dahomey #ayiticherie

Recognize that lady on the wall? She may look like Mary as Our Lady of Sorrows but she's actually representative of Erzulie Freda--a Vodou spirit (loa) associated with love. Did you know that Vodou and Catholicism are syncretic? The origin story of Vodou is as such (boiled down for an instagram caption but bear with me): when slaves were brought to Hispaniola from West Africa, a mix of religions from different areas of West Africa came along with the slaves. The slaves weren't allowed to practice their religions from home--religious worship was based around the Catholic faith (enforced by slavemasters). Because they weren't able to freely practice their religion, they started associating their spirits with images from Catholicism to practice under cover of plain sight. Here in Haiti, if you see an image of Saint Peter it could be for Saint Peter or it could be representative of loa Papa Legba. For many, it's both. There is a saying that Haiti is "70% Catholic, 30% Protestant and 100% Vodou." Vodou is often persecuted by Christian denominations, but for many vodouizans Christian imagery and dual-belief (for example: being Catholic and vodouizan) are just part of the practice. For more from Haiti, follow me along on my personal account at @meghandhaliwal and follow my reporting partner @beenishfahmed  #vodou #voodoo #irpfellows #voodoodoll #haiti #catholicism #virginmary #erzuliefreda

Two days before Wisconsin's presidential primary, @berniesanders is holding a massive rally at the state's largest university. He's slightly ahead of @hillaryclinton in the polls, but will Wisconsin feel the Bern on Tuesday? @alicemirandao will have the details from the ground.

Being in Haiti and reporting on Vodou means learning new things every day. Yesterday we visited the Museum of Ethnology in Port au Prince and learned this upsetting fact: during the time the American forces occupied Haiti (1915-1934) officials banned Vodou from being practiced in Haiti. Drums were made illegal for their significance in Vodou ceremonies (different beats communicate and call for different spirits) and Marines would often confiscate them and sell them to art collectors or galleries in the US. When dancer Katherine Dunham came to Haiti in the mid-thirties after the US occupation had ended, she said she would still come across drums hidden in hollow tree trunks or behind waterfalls. In this image, drums sit in a peristyle (Vodou temple). For more from Haiti, follow me along on my personal account at @meghandhaliwal and follow my reporting partner @beenishfahmed  #vodou #voodoo #irpfellows #voodoodoll #haiti 
#ayiticherie #peristyle

Okay, we need to talk about Vodou dolls. Are they one of the first things that come to your mind when you think of Vodou? Images of magical vengeance dancing through your head? Well, first I'll give you this: they do exist. Here is a picture of one at a botanica in Gonaives. BUT they aren't common and they aren't for the purpose that you're imagining. Vodou dolls are much more complicated than Hollywood portrays. Often stuffed with different kind of herbs, leaves or flower petals depending on what the buyer needs it for, they then might have a personal artifact from the person the doll symbolizes attached to it (allegedly this is where the pin imagery comes from). The dolls can be used at home or left in a special place (the main cemetery in Port-au-Prince has a tree with hundreds of dolls nailed to it). The dolls are a way to communicate with the spirits, or loa, about the wishes or needs for a particular person. Sometimes these have to do with bringing people back--either from a physical place or emotionally, or health. These dolls aren't usually used for bad things. Of course, the power belongs to those who wield it--in Vodou they say, "Everyone has a left hand and a right hand." With everything that can be made light, there is also an option to make it dark. But the perversion of the Vodou doll came from Hollywood sensationalization--not from the botanicas of Haiti. For more from Haiti, follow me along on my personal account at @meghandhaliwal and follow my reporting partner @beenishfahmed  #vodou #voodoo #irpfellows #voodoodoll #haiti #nopinshere

@meghandhaliwal here, reporting with another snapshot of my and @beenishfahmed's time in Haiti reporting on Vodou. The picture you're seeing was taken maybe two hours after we landed in Haiti on the road from Port-au-Prince to Gonaives--we really hit the ground running! This group was part of a massive RaRa band marching along the highway we were driving on. RaRa is a type of festival music unique to Haiti, and lucky us the peak season to get caught in a RaRa band on the highway is Easter week. RaRa is closely tied with Vodou--there are often Vodou themes in the songs and dances. It was perfect timing for us: we were headed up to Souvenance for one of the bigger Vodou ceremonies in the country, so this was the perfect primer. #haiti #ayiticherie #vodou #voodoo #rara #raraband #irpfellows

Hey everyone! This is @meghandhaliwal reporting from Haiti alongside fabulous @thinkprogress reporter @beenishfahmed. We're here in Haiti on a grant from the @internationalreportingproject looking at the religion of Vodou. Vodou, or Voodoo, is a complex religion made up of many spirits, or loa (or lwa), and tailor-made to Haiti itself. Stemming from West Africa, Vodou morphed in to its own unique religion during the time of the slave trade--when slaves on the island of Hispaniola were kept from practicing the religion of their homelands by slavemasters. Multiple West African traditions blended together with a pinch of Catholicism (we'll talk about this more later) and Vodou was born. It has played an important part of the fabric of Haitian society for even longer than Haiti has existed as its own independent country--in fact, Vodou played an important role in the founding of Haiti (we'll talk about this more too). We're so excited to be here looking past the Vodou of Hollywood--we'll be sharing snapshots of our trip here for the next week. In this image, initiates wait to walk to the Mapou tree in Souvenance. The ceremonies in Souvenance are a highlight of Vodou ceremonies each year--people come from all over the country to participate or to spectate. This moment is peaceful: vacillating between reverent and joyful as the participants sing ancient songs with roots in West Africa. According to participant Betty Vaval, "When we walk to the Mapou, we walk from Haiti to Benin." #haiti #ayiticherie #souvenance #vodou #voodoo #irpfellows

A sign warns Israeli citizens not to enter a Palestinian city within "Area A" of the occupied West Bank, saying it could be "dangerous to [their] lives." Signs like these are common throughout the region, which was split into three administrative sectors by the Oslo II Accord in 1996.

Area A, which makes up around 3 percent of the land, is governed and controlled by the Palestinian Authority (PA). Area B constitutes roughly 23-25 percent the West Bank, where the PA oversees civil matters and a joint PA-Israeli force provides security. Around 72 percent of the West Bank was initially registered as Area C, which is fully controlled by the Israeli government.

Although Israeli citizens are barred from entering Area A, the military is allowed to conduct raids to arrest suspected militants. Meanwhile, Palestinians are barred from developing in Area C, where the Israeli government regularly builds new towns -- even though the United Nations claims such settlements are illegal under international law.

Palestinians sometimes build in Area C anyway, but typically have their constructions demolished by the government.

##

This is @jackjenkins reporting from Israel-Palestine. #Israel #Palestine #WestBank #Occupation

‚ÄúWe live in fear 24 hours a day.‚Äù That‚Äôs how Mofid Sharabati, a Palestinian, described his life in Hebron, a city in the occupied West Bank. Sharabati and his children live in a small house down the street from an Israeli checkpoint that divides a Palestinian section of the city from an Israeli settlement. Sharabati resides on the Israeli side of the checkpoint, where many other Palestinians have abandoned their homes, due in part to claims of harassment from Israeli settlers and soldiers that patrol the area.

Sharabati, however, refuses to leave. ‚ÄúThis has been my family‚Äôs home for 150 years,‚Äù he said defiantly, speaking through a translator.

Sharabati claims to have been the subject of beatings at the hands of officials, and showed a group of journalists x-rays of pins used to rebuild his spine after one incident. He said his 10-year-old son Marwan, pictured above, was also detained by police earlier this month. His crime: holding a stone.

The family‚Äôs latest run-in with Israeli officials came last week, when an armed settler shot and killed an 18-year-old Palestinian directly outside Sharabati‚Äôs house, where the street is still stained with blood. Authorities say the man attempted to stab the settler with a knife ‚Äî the weapon of choice for many Palestinians who have attacked Israeli soldiers and citizens in recent weeks. But a video recorded from Sharabati‚Äôs window shows officials placing something next to his dying body. Local Palestinians cite this as proof that the soldiers planted evidence.

When the military learned of the video, Sharabati says they raided his home, confiscated his camera and laptop, and broke them. They also arrested his brother, who emailed the video to others.

Since then, the atmosphere in his home ‚Äî like most of Israel and Palestine ‚Äî has been tense. ‚ÄúThis is the life we live every day,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe live in fear they could come back into our home at any time. There is always someone awake.‚Äù ## 
This is @jackjenkins reporting from Israel-Palestine. #Israel #Palestine #Occupation #WestBank

A journalist holds aloft a used Israeli sound bomb in Hebron, a city in the occupied West Bank. Government forces often use such devices to disperse Palestinian protests.

Used sound bombs and empty tear gas canisters littered the street in front of a key checkpoint in Hebron on Tuesday, left over from spontaneous demonstrations that erupted after Israeli soldiers shot three young men and boys over the last week. Israeli authorities say the felled youngsters attempted to stab soldiers, an increasingly common occurrence during the region‚Äôs recent uptick in violence.

However, many Palestinians in Hebron claim defense forces planted a knife on one of the teenagers, pointing to a cell phone video showing a soldier placing something next to the body of 18-year-old Fadel Mohammed al-Qawasameh. Locals also expressed sustained outrage over the shooting of a woman at the checkpoint on September 22nd, arguing she was killed unnecessarily.

##

This is @jackjenkins reporting from Israel-Palestine. #Israel #Palestine #WestBank #Occupation

Graffiti adorning one of the many separation walls in the West Bank, this one near Har Gillo. Originally launched as an Israeli government project to ward off suicide bombings, the walls have since become the symbol of occupation to most Palestinians in the region. Upon completion, the barrier -- which includes barb wire fences -- is projected to stretch around 430 miles.

##

This is @jackjenkins reporting from Israel-Palestine. #Israel #Palestine #Jerusalem

People wait in line on Sunday at a "flying checkpoint" outside Isawiyya, a Palestinian neighborhood in East Jerusalem. Israeli security forces have erected several new checkpoints around the city in response to a recent uptick in violence, which included the stabbings of several guards at the hands of Palestinian assailants. At least 35 Palestinians have been shot dead by troops since September, some during stabbing attacks and others during clashes with government forces in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. Eight Israelis have been killed in that same time. 
Palestinians are told to approach checkpoints slowly and present identification to armed officers. Men are forced to turn around and lift up their shirts. Around 3,500 police patrolled the streets throughout the weekend, and several roads have been blocked off entirety.

##

This is @jackjenkins reporting from Israel-Palestine. #Israel #Palestine #Jerusalem

Much of Mombasa is stunning, but that doesn't mean it's without a dark side. On Friday night, I met a 17 year old girl named Batini* who has been living on the beach since post-election violence shook Kenya in 2007. "Men flash their car lights at me and I go over to them but I say I need to buy food before I'll do anything. When they give me money, I just run away," she said. 
The story seemed implausible. I asked Paul Nganga about her. He works for Okoa Sasa, an organization that rescues children from sex work. He used to work on the beach Batini works on. Nganga said she's been a sex worker since she arrived in Mombasa. "I found her at around 6:00 [in the morning one day]. She was naked. She was bleeding everywhere," Nganga said. He took Batini to the hospital. She had been gang raped in the parking lot and managed to make it to a boat for safety. After I spoke to her, Okoa Sasa offered Batini a home plus the opportunity to attend school and leave sex work behind. She was intrigued but skeptical. [*This name has been changed.]
###
-- @beenishfahmed here, wrapping up my reporting trip to Kenya. Watch ThinkProgress.org for this and more stories from my two weeks here. 
#Mombasa #Kenya #beach #womensrights #girlsrights #rape #sexwork

Just as women enter their 20s, their risk of poverty spikes dramatically. Then, women experience another gap as they approach their 80s. Why?

Children and the death of spouses.

"Are you a woman or a man?" the police asked Kennedy* when he walked into the station with a massive gash on his head. He had been beat up by an ex-lover but the police refused to take his report until he proved he had sex with women. He texted a female friend and asked her to pretend to be his girlfriend. It was only after the cops talked to her that they took his report. 
Gay sex is illegal in Kenya, which means that many LGBT people are afraid to report violence committed against them to the police. Their experiences show a system stacked against them because of their sexual identities. [*This name has been changed.]
###
-- This is @beenishfahmed reporting from Kenya, a country where gay sex is a crime that carries up to 14 years in prison. [* This name has been changed.]
#Mombasa #Kenya #LGBT #LGBTrights #humanrights

"One [of my clients] came to know that I'm a lesbian and he beat me up. He had a knife. He stabbed me," Marion,* a Mombasa-based sex worker said. Other sex workers blackmail her about her sexuality regularly, she said, but she can't report them because of sex work and same-sex relationships are both illegal in Kenya.
[*This name has been changed.]
###
-- This is @beenishfahmed reporting from Kenya through a grant from the @ICFJ. [* This name has been changed.]
#Mombasa #Kenya #LGBT #LGBTrights #humanrights

One of Musa's* friends came to him one night, bucked over and bleeding. He had been sitting on the rocks by the beach when five police officers began to harass him. "If you're going to go swimming, then undress." Musa's friend did as he was told and was then raped by each of the cops. Musa insisted his friend go to the police station to report the incident and when he reported the gang rape to the officer there what happened, the cop said with a surprised tone, "And he's alive [after all that]?" The cop said if the friend had been raped, he should take off his clothes and show them the evidence. Musa insisted that he came to file a case. The police said they were there to protect people not rape people, and said they should leave or face a night in jail. They left. [*This name has been changed.]
###
-- This is @beenishfahmed reporting from Kenya through a grant from the @ICFJ. [* This name has been changed.]
#Mombasa #Kenya #LGBT #LGBTrights #humanrights #journalism #notesfromthefield

Kenya is one of the 79 countries around the world where homosexuality is a crime. Many LGBT people fear being outed not only because of social stigma, but because of laws against homosexual acts that can be punished with up to 14 years in prison. A dark economy has grown around this grim reality in which people believed to be LGBT are blackmailed to pay steep amounts or, ironically, forced to have sex with someone of the same gender to avoid being outed. 
Michael Kioko is a Mombasa-based lawyer who has handled many such cases. He told me that LGBT people are often caught between a rock and a hard place. "They will not readily go to the police to report [being extorted] because they fear that they will be asked the reason for their blackmail," he said. "They fear that the police will zero in on the reason and forget the blackmail and then they'll get themselves in even more trouble." ###
-- This is @beenishfahmed, World Reporter at ThinkProgress. Watch this space for the rest of this week for more of my reporting from Kenya.
#Mombasa #Kenya #LGBT #lawyer #LBGTrights #üåà

On September 15, 1963, 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Alabama was bombed by four Ku Klux Klan members, killing four black girls and injuring 22 others. 
Today, we remember the tragic loss of life that proved to be a turning point in the Civil Rights Movement while recognizing that racial violence against black Americans persists to today, over 50 years after the signing of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

Children play in a spot of Dandora, Nairobi that used to be covered in trash. An estimated 6,000 people earn their living from picking through a 30-acre landfill for recyclables to sell. Due to a new community-driven initiative, however, a few of them no longer have to come home to a dump after working in one all day. 
###
-- This is @beenishfahmed reporting from Kenya. 
#Nairobi #Kenya #development #recycle #neighborhood

"All over, there was garbage. If you stood here, someone on the other side could not see you," Richard Munene, a Dandora resident and restaurant owner said as he washed his car on a sunny afternoon. "Even someone could attack you and you couldn't see...but now you're ok because you can see everything." He sites the project Gashanga launched for renewing safety in his community, and pride too. 
###
-- This is @beenishfahmed, World Reporter at ThinkProgress, with news from Kenya. 
#Nairobi #Kenya #community #neighborhood.

When Charles Gashanga moved back to his neighborhood of Dandora in Nairobi, Kenya from Tanzania, he decided it was time to make a change. The area had long been a dump -- literally. Just a couple hundred meters away from where he posed for this photo is the city's only landfill. Although it was deemed full in 2001, the trash kept coming. It even filled the small courtyards around area homes. He started around his own home and now runs a courtyard remodeling competition to spur change across Dandora.
###
-- This is @beenishfahmed, World Reporter at ThinkProgress offering up dispatches from my trip to Kenya. 
#Dandora #Nairobi #Kenya #neighborhood #cleanup #development

There are some giggles and snickers, but overall, the boys in this class take the survey on rape prevention seriously. One high school freshman said he went to a neighbor's birthday party and found him trying to force a girl to have sex with him. "I went into his room and told her to run," he said. "I took a beating for it." An average of one in four girls in Nairobi's largest slums report being a victim of sexual violence. The brave high schooler in this class might have saved one of them. 
###
-- This is @beenishfahmed, World Reporter at ThinkProgress, documenting notes from Kenya. 
#Nairobi #Kenya #rape #vaw #boys #girls #highschool

This is the survey that high school boys in Nairobi who participated in Ujaama Kenya's "Your Moment of Truth" campaign take after the six-week program. Before the program, 80 percent of boys said they thought a girls in "sexy dress" invited sex. Afterwards, it dropped to 30 percent. 
###
-- This is @beenishfahmed, World Reporter at ThinkProgress. I'll be sharing field notes from my trip to Kenya here for another week. 
#Nairobi #Kenya #consent #sexed #vaw #girls #boys

"We tell girls, 'Don't get raped,' but we never tell boys 'Don't rape,'" Benjamin Omondi told me. His organization, Ujaama Africa, is trying to remedy that with a 6-week program that teaches high school boys about the concept of consent and how they can intervene to stop sexual violence.
###
-- This is @beenishfahmed reporting from Kenya through a grant from the @icfj. Watch ThinkProgress.org for the rest of my story on this unique initiative.
#Nairobi #Kenya #vaw #boys #girls #rape #rapeculture #fieldnotes #highschool

One of my favorite things to look out for while traveling is how names, logos, and slogans are repurposed in interesting and often arbitrary ways. This shop overlooking Kenya's Great Rift Valley sells sheepskin rugs and beaded jewelry but someone apparently thought "Facebook" was a fitting namesake. 
###
This is @beenishfahmed reporting from Kenya. 
#Kenya #Facebook #travel #codeswitch #confusion

Kenya passed a law outlawing FGM in 2011 and appointed 20 prosecutors across the country to deal with FGM cases last year. Although there's a system in place to combat the practice, it remains incredibly challenging to do so since many of its victims are unwilling to testify against their neighbors, relatives, or even parents. Others are coerced into silence. "FGM cases are the most challenging ones we deal with," Gitongo Muriuki, the head prosecutor in Narok County, told me. That's why many of women's and children's rights organizations  prefer to try to rescue and then reconcile victims of FGM with their families than take them to court. 
###
-- This is @beenishfahmed, World Reporter at ThinkProgress. I'm in Kenya reporting on women's and LGBT right. 
#Narok #Kenya #women #girls #fgm #law
If you need help, please take a moment to call. #nationalsuicidepreventionday

"He was around 70 years old," Rhoda Kishoyean, 13, says of the man she was due to marry at the age of 9. Instead, she packed her bags and ran away. "I don't blame [my parents] because it is their culture, she said. Her culture, she said, is different. It's about maintaining women's and girl's rights. 
Although Kishoyean had never stepped foot inside a classroom before she fled her village, she always knew she wanted to be "an important person." She hopes to become a prosecutor and work on cases of FGM and early marriage. Watch ThinkProgress.org for the rest of her story. 
###
-- This is @beenishfahmed, World Reporter at ThinkProgress. I'll be taking over this account with my reporting from #Kenya for the next two weeks.
(Photo credit: Maren Okoth)
#Narok #Kenya #womensrights #girlsrights #vaw #FGM #school #education #law

"We love [our mother], we respect her, but we don't trust her," says Agnes Letura (right), 15. She and her sister Mesey, 16, ran away from home four years ago after their mother insisted they undergo FGM. They have never gone back and don't plan to until they complete their educations. Watch ThinkProgress for my story on how these two brave girls defied cultural expectations and changed the course of their lives before they reached the age of 13.
###
-- This is @beenishfahmed, World Reporter at ThinkProgress. I'll be Kenya for the next two weeks through a grant from the @ICFJ. Follow along on my reporting here.
#Narok #Kenya #vaw #FGM #womensrights #girlsrights

"My mom, my grandmother, everyone was screaming, talking about me and saying that I was a coward because I couldn't face the knife. The story turned. It was no longer a matter of me saying no to FGM, it was a matter of me being a coward, and the worst thing you can ever call a Masai [person] is a coward," Agnes Pareyio told me. She underwent FGM even though she had promised her best friend at boarding school that she wouldn't. When she returned there after break, she was too ashamed to explain what happened, but vowed to save other girls from the fate she suffered. Stay tuned to ThinkProgress for my full report on Pareyio's work to stop FGM amongst the Masai in Kenya. 
###
--This is @beenishfahmed, World Reporter at ThinkProgress. I'll be taking over this Instagram feed for two weeks with dispatches from my reporting in Kenya.
#Narok #Kenya #Masai #FGM #vaw #womensrights #girlsrights #activist

We had to stop at the #zebra crossing.

This is @beenishfahmed, World Reporter at ThinkProgress. I'll be taking over this account for two weeks as I roam around #Kenya.

"To stop the poacher, the trader must be stopped and to stop the trader, the final buyer must be convinced not to buy ivory," Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi said in 1989 before setting fire to 12 tons of elephant tusks. The move was lauded by animal welfare organizations and many others countries, including, most recently, Thailand, have since burned their stockpiles of found and confiscated ivory. While an important symbolic gesture, many argue that destroying ivory only makes it rarer and thus more valuable. For more on the controversy around destroying ivory, read my article on the topic here: http://thkpr.gs/3696414. 
###
This is @beenishfahmed, World Reporter at ThinkProgress. I'll be taking over this account for two weeks with dispatches from Kenya.

My first stop in Kenya was the Nairobi National Park, the only national park in the world that borders a national capital. It's amazing to see zebras, impala, giraffes, baboons, and even predators like cheetahs roam against the backdrop of the city. But just because they're on a guarded and gated land doesn't mean they're safe. Last year, poachers hacked off the horns of a black rhino and left it to die inside the park. While Kenya has tried to crack down on poaching, demand keeps the illegal industry alive. So much so that rhino horns are now more valuable than gold or cocaine.
###
This is @beenishfahmed, World Reporter for ThinkProgress. I'll be taking over the account with photos from Kenya for the next two weeks.
